awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Caught in the Act- The Petrology of Modern Lower-Crust Formation and Foundering in the North Andean Arc
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's continents are thought to have mainly formed in convergent tectonic boundaries, where hydrous fluids transported to depth by subducting plates enable melting of the upper mantle and produce magmas that ultimately contribute to the growth of the overlying crust. Nevertheless, the processes responsible for driving the composition of primitive magmas generated in arc regions, which are basaltic, towards the bulk composition that characterizes Earth's continents, which are andesitic, remain intensely debated. A major difficulty in understanding these 'differentiation' processes, and how they may couple with other first-order features of convergent continental margins, is the fact that the deep roots of these magmatically-active regions are rarely exposed in the Earth?s surface. However, volcanic eruptions are sometimes capable of transporting deep-sourced rock fragments ?known as 'xenoliths'- to the Earth's surface, providing Earth scientists with unique glimpses of processes occurring deep within the continents that are otherwise difficult to study. 

In the northern segment of the Andean orogen (southern Colombia), a rare eruption from a recent volcanic vent transported an extraordinary cargo of xenolith fragments sourced from the deep roots of the arc and mantle section beneath it. Therefore, this locality presents a unique opportunity to help unravel the physical and chemical processes that operate during construction of continental crust in magmatically-active regions like the Andes. This award supports two early-career Assistant Professors and a woman who is a PhD student to conduct a detailed geochemical, petrologic and geochronologic study of these unique xenoliths, and the rare eruptions that brought them to the surface. In particular, this research focuses on the 'gravitationally unstable' root of the arc, a section of crustal (i.e., chemically differentiated) rocks with densities greater than the underlying mantle, represented by lithologies such as garnet gabbros, hornblendites, and garnet-bearing pyroxenites. Mechanical removal of density-unstable roots form the base of arcs, a process known as lithospheric foundering (aka, delamination), has not only been identified as a crucial process to explain the chemistry of Earth's continents but is also thought capable of inducing rapid changes in surface elevation, such as those driving the fast Neogene uplift of the Central Andean Plateau. Because the processes taking place in the lower orogenic crust are critical for understanding the uplift history of mountains, the geochemistry of the continents, and the geophysical imaging of the deep lithosphere, results from this investigation will have important implications for our understanding of the geochemical, structural and tectonic history of Andean-type plate margins. In addition to the scientific research products that will result from this investigation, the PIs will collaborate with the Rochester Museum and Science Center (RMSC) on activities that will: 1) explain the origin and physicochemical principles of arc volcanoes to the public of Upstate NY; and 2) continue to organize campus visits for high-school participants of RMSC's 'Next Level Science' summer camps, to provide local students with a direct opportunity to experience college and learn more about upper-level STEM education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to answer long-standing questions regarding the processes involved in the evolving chemical composition of Earth’s continental crust – the uppermost layer of our planet. In particular, our project used geochemical studies of rocks from volcanoes located in the Northern Andes to investigate possible recycling of this uppermost layer into the deep part of the Earth – the mantle. Rocks from the Northern Andes are the perfect material for this study because this region is one of the few places where these processes are occurring in the modern and can be observed using multiple techniques and approaches. The material from the crust is believed to descend into the mantle and change the chemistry of the mantle rocks that form a “root” beneath the volcanoes of this region. The changing chemistry results in a very dense root that may last for a long-time or break-off rapidly and drop deep into the mantle with implications for the landscape of the Northern Andes.

Our work involved processing hundreds of new rock samples from the crust and from the mantle for a suite of geochemical and geochronological analyses to investigate the timing of recycling and the depths at which recycling may have occurred. By using some innovative geochemical techniques were were able to analyze these exceptional samples with a toolkit that has been hitherto under-employed in samples from these kind of geological settings. The results from our project revealed that the volcanic rocks we sampled are much younger than previously thought and thus provide a “fresher” perspective on deep Earth processes than existing sample sets. Additionally, the distinct geochemistry of these samples indicates that many of the mantle rocks clearly have a crustal signature – suggesting there was active recycling and contamination of the mantle beneath this region prior to eruption. Some of the analyzed samples have geochemical markers that we interpret as evidence of crust contaminating mantle samples which then became dense enough to sink into the mantle but were caught and brought to the surface via the volcanism. Building upon these fascinating new findings we have started to re-evaluate many previous sample sets that we have “in-house” that may shed light on “fossil” examples of crust-mantle interactions. Our team traveled to Spain and France to sample and collaborate with European researchers who are working on volcanic rocks from areas that have been considered to be canonical for these topics. We believe that we are now exceptionally well placed to ask new questions about these crust-mantle processes but using samples from other regions, we can evaluate how these processes changed over Earth history. This project was the foundation for training of one PhD student, and multiple undergraduate students at both Yale and University of Arizona/Rochester. Furthermore, the team at Yale and U of Arizona carried out outreach activities within local school districts (K-12 and high school).
